fredo 1.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Using fredo for FRED Data Analysis in R

    plot_fredo: Generate plots for FRED data

    plot_fredo.Rd

    This function takes a dataset extracted from the FRED API, creates plots for each unique FRED variable, saves those plots as PDFs, and optionally generates LaTeX code for inclusion in documents.

    plot_fredo(
  dataset,
  path,
  start = "1950-01-01",
  end = "2024-12-31",
  combine = FALSE,
  show_recessions = TRUE,
  generate_latex = FALSE,
  plot_width = 14.14,
  plot_height = 10
)

    Arguments

    dataset

    A data frame containing FRED data with columns 'title', 'date', 'value', 'id', 'notes', and 'units_short'.

    path

    A character string specifying the directory path where plots will be saved.

    start

    The start date for filtering the data (format: 'YYYY-MM-DD').

    end

    The end date for filtering the data (format: 'YYYY-MM-DD').

    combine

    A logical value. If TRUE, plots all series on a single graph; if FALSE, creates individual plots.

    show_recessions

    A logical value. If TRUE, includes recession bars in the plots; if FALSE, omits them.

    generate_latex

    A logical value. If TRUE, generates LaTeX code for the plots; if FALSE, skips LaTeX generation.

    plot_width

    The width of the plot in centimeters. Default is 14.14.

    plot_height

    The height of the plot in centimeters. Default is 10.

    Value

    This function does not return a value. It generates plots, saves them as PDFs, and optionally prints LaTeX code.

    Examples

    # Example 1: Plot each series individually without recession bars (default plot size)
plot_fredo(
  dataset = fred_data,
  path = "output_directory/",
  start = '1950-01-01',
  end = '2024-12-31',
  combine = FALSE,
  show_recessions = FALSE,
  generate_latex = TRUE
)
#> 
#> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’:
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'fred_data' not found

# Example 2: Combine all series into one plot with recession bars (custom plot size)
plot_fredo(
  dataset = fred_data,
  path = "output_directory/",
  start = '1950-01-01',
  end = '2024-12-31',
  combine = TRUE,
  show_recessions = TRUE,
  generate_latex = TRUE,
  plot_width = 20,  # Custom width
  plot_height = 15  # Custom height
)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'fred_data' not found

# Example 3: Plot each series individually with recession bars (custom plot size)
plot_fredo(
  dataset = fred_data,
  path = "output_directory/",
  start = '1950-01-01',
  end = '2024-12-31',
  combine = FALSE,
  show_recessions = TRUE,
  generate_latex = TRUE,
  plot_width = 16,  # Custom width
  plot_height = 12  # Custom height
)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'fred_data' not found

# Example 4: Combine all series into one plot without generating LaTeX code (default plot size)
plot_fredo(
  dataset = fred_data,
  path = "output_directory/",
  start = '1950-01-01',
  end = '2024-12-31',
  combine = TRUE,
  show_recessions = FALSE,
  generate_latex = FALSE
)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'fred_data' not found
